turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh, isn't it?

turn.speaker: barbara_e_etkind
turn.label: Ms. Barbara E. Etkind
turn.text: The vast majority of our easements are perpetual easements.
I was told by Interior 99 percent, but that is not in the record.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What is in the record on that point?

turn.speaker: barbara_e_etkind
turn.label: Ms. Barbara E. Etkind
turn.text: What is in the record is reflected in our brief.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If it's in your brief I'll find it.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: barbara_e_etkind
turn.label: Ms. Barbara E. Etkind
turn.text: In particular, North Dakota Centennial Code Section 20.10218.3 purports to suspend gubernatorial consent to federal acquisition of any land or interest in land with money from the Migratory Bird Conservation Fund.
Now, since this provision amounts to a straightforward revocation of consent, it is void as inconsistent with federal law for the reasons I've already discussed.
I see that my time is up.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you have anything further, Mr. Attorney General?

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: Yes, sir, I do, Mr. Chief Justice.
Let me just focus real quickly on this questions of the constitutionality of our laws with respect to the argument made again in oral argument by the United States.
They are suggesting that our laws are constitutional to any consents that may go on beyond this 1.3 or 1.5 million acres.
In other words, our laws are constitutional.

The only thing that makes our laws unconstitutional with respect to the United States is that insofar as they purport to condition the acquisition by the Federal Government of another 600 or 700,000 acres, that that constitutes a revocation or a conditioning, in that they cannot do that, and that revocation or conditioning is indeed an impediment to us.
The last section that my sister just mentioned, 18.103, does not revoke, It simply suspends until the Federal Government of the United States gets together or December 31st, 1983.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Attorney General.

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Is the present Governor Olson the former Attorney General of your state?

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, did Governor revoke or not?

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: Governor Link... we cannot find a single document where Governor Link said, I revoke these consents signed by myself and governor Guy.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if he said, I will never... I will not agree to any further acquisitions, if some piece of land the United States claimed was covered by a prior consent and Governor Link says, I will not agree to that, has he in effect revoked or not?

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: The only fair reading of that statement made by Governor Link is that it relates to the fee lands and not to the easements.
Let me explain why this consent--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You still say, then, that the prior consents have never been revoked by a Governor?

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: --There is no written document to that effect, that's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or no conduct by them.

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: There's plenty of conduct to the effect, but there is no written document.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That they revoked?

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: Yes.
The United States has treated them as revoked.
We treat them as revoked.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the Eighth Circuit said they were revoked, too.

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: Yes.
Indeed, and so did the district court.
Let me explain how this came up--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In your argument on direct you said they weren't revoked, I thought.

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: --Well, they are not revoked through an action of our Governor where he signs a paper saying, I hereby revoke these particular previous consents.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But you've taken the position that the legal effect is they've been revoked.

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That's the position you've taken throughout this litigation until this afternoon, right?

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: In terms of the Governor's signature, that's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: We should judge the case on the ground that North Dakota's legal position is that the consents have purported to have been revoked.

turn.speaker: robert_o_wefald
turn.label: Mr. Robert O. Wefald
turn.text: Well, that's correct.
Let me tell you what came up at the district court level, just to clear this up.
The United States sued us.
Their complaint sought to declare unconstitutional our laws.
That's all.
At the end of the oral argument the judge suggested, well, I don't think consent's necessary.
Thereafter followed the stipulation, in a very curious order of events, and it has subsequently snowballed to this particular point.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at 10:00.
